all_summaries: This paper introduces FramePack, a novel memory structure and anti-drifting sampling methods for next-frame prediction models in video generation, addressing the forgetting-drifting dilemma by compressing input frames based on their importance to limit context length and using bi-directional context through early-established endpoints or inverted temporal sampling to reduce error propagation. Key findings include that inverted anti-drifting sampling achieves superior performance across multiple metrics, including all drifting metrics, and that generating more frames per section improves perceptual quality. Additionally, FramePack enables efficient video generation with fixed computational bottlenecks and is compatible with existing video diffusion models.

This paper introduces FramePack, an anti-forgetting memory structure and anti-drifting sampling methods for next-frame prediction in video generation, which addresses the forgetting-drifting dilemma by compressing input frames based on their importance, ensuring a fixed upper bound on total context length, and incorporating bi-directional context through endpoint frames or inverted temporal order. Key findings include that inverted anti-drifting sampling achieves top performance in multiple metrics and human evaluations, while FramePack improves model efficiency and visual quality, enabling longer video generation without increasing computational bottlenecks.
summary: This paper introduces FramePack, an anti-forgetting memory structure and anti-drifting sampling methods for next-frame prediction in video generation, which addresses the forgetting-drifting dilemma by compressing input frames based on their importance, ensuring a fixed upper bound on total context length, and incorporating bi-directional context through endpoint frames or inverted temporal order. Key findings include that inverted anti-drifting sampling achieves top performance in multiple metrics and human evaluations, while FramePack improves model efficiency and visual quality, enabling longer video generation without increasing computational bottlenecks.
